abstract.para: &App; provides a way for blind individuals to access scanned sheet music in a convenient format (&bmn;).
This book serves as an introduction to &bmn; for those readers that are not familiar with it yet. It is also the User's Manual for &App;.

partintro.para: &Bmn; is an internationally accepted standard for notating music for visually impaired musicians in a tactile form. &Bmn; was originally developed by Louis Braille.

&Bmn; uses the same six-position Braille cell as literary braille. However braille music assigns an entirely separate meaning to each braille symbol or group of symbols, different from literary braille, and has its own syntax and abbreviations.

Since &App; is mostly useless to a user who can not read &bmn;, the first part of this book is dedicated to teaching the very basics of &bmn;. If you are already familiar with the international &bmn; standard, you can safely skip over this section.
Also, german speaking readers might like to refer to the Neues internationales Handbuch der Braillenotenschrift (new international handbook of braille music notation) available from the internet.

sect1.title: Notes and rests
sect1.para: The pitch of the notes are indicated by dots 1, 2, 4, and 5. The absence or presence of dots 3 and/or 6 determines the note rhythmic values. Each note or rest has two rhythmic value possibilities.

For dotted notes, dot 3 represents each print dot following a note. It is placed immediately after the braille note. No other sign comes between the note and its dot(s). Dotted rests are treated the same as dotted notes.

sect1.title: Octave marks
sect1.para: Octave marks, rather than clefs on a staff, indicate specific pitch locations in braille music. Octaves are numbered from one to seven, beginning with the lowest C on the normal, seven-octave piano. Each octave begins on C and includes all the notes up to, but not including, the next C above. The fourth octave begins on the "middle C" of the piano.
The octave mark is placed immediately before the note to which it applies with no intervening signs. The following table shows the octave marks from 1 to 7 placed before quarter-note C.
The first note of a piece must be preceded by its octave mark. For the succeeding notes the following rules apply:

listitem.para: if the next note forms an ascending or descending second or third, it does not receive an octave mark even if it is in a different octave.
if it forms an ascending or descending fourth or fifth, it only receives an octave mark if it is in a different octave from the preceding note.
if it forms a sixth or more, it must always have its own octave mark.

sect1.title: Accidentals
sect1.para: The following table lists the symbols used to indicate accidentals.
The sharp, flat and natural signs are placed before the notes, intervals or other features to which they belong. They must not be separated from notes by anything other than octave marks.
If an accidental appears above or below a note in print, it is preceded by dot 6 in braille.

sect1.title: Key signatures
sect1.para: Key signatures reflect the number of flats or sharps, not the actual pitches as in print. If there are four or more accidentals in a key signature, the number sign (dots 3, 4, 5, 6) is used.
The next note following a key signature must have an octave mark. If it is not followed by a time signature, it must be followed by a space.

sect1.title: Time signatures
sect1.para: When time signatures consist of an upper and a lower number in print, the braille uses upper- and lower-cell numbers with a number sign only at the beginning of the combination. An upper-cell number is used for a single-digit time signature. In other types of signatures as well, the print is followed closely.
A time signature must be followed by a space, and the next note following it must have an octave mark.
The key and time signatures are combined with or without one space between, according to the practice of the nation. This is not implemented yet, time and key signatures are combined without a space.

chapter.title: Contrapuntal lines and chords within a staff
chapter.para: Unlike print music notation, braille music is an entirely linear format. Therefore certain conventions must be used to indicate contrapuntal lines and chords, situations where more than one note is played simultaneously within a single staff.

sect1.title: In-accords
sect1.para: Independent contrapuntal lines within a single staff are indicated via whole-measure or part-measure "in-accords".

sect1.title: Interval notation
sect1.para: Homophonic chordal sections are written using interval notation.

partintro.para: &App; is not a full &omr; solution. To be able to read sheet music, you will first need to obtain the music you want to read with &App; in MusicXML format.
The following chapters are concerned with how and where you can obtain sheet music in MusicXML.

chapter.title: What is MusicXML?
chapter.para: MusicXML is a &XML; based file format for storing musical notation. It is being developed by Recordare LLC.

chapter.title: How to create MusicXML scores?
chapter.para: MusicXML is now supported by almost all commercial and a number of free applications dealing with musical scores in one way or another. There are basically two ways to obtain a score in MusicXML format. Either you already have it in some computerized form, then you need to investigate how to convert your data to MusicXML. Many commercial notation editors offer a way to export to MusicXML these days. If you have the music on paper, you need some &omr; software to scan and recognize your music and then export to MusicXML.
A list of applications that allow to save or export to MusicXML format can be found on the recordare website.

sect1.title: Using Sibelius to create MusicXML documents

sect2.title: Fingering
sect2.para:
There are three types of text in Sibelius
Staff text: text that applies to a single staff, typically directions for a single instrument
System text: text that applies to all staves in the score (though it may only be displayed above one or two of them), and which will appear in all parts (if there are any) -- typically tempo or rehearsal directions
Blank page text: text that can only be created on a blank page, typically performance directions or other front matter.

If you plan to export your score to MusicXML with Dolet for Sibelius so that you can import it in another music notation program or have Freedots transcribe your score, Then you not only have to make sure to use the right text type, but also the right font and style.
You achieve this by using the word menus, that most Sibelius text edit dialogs provide.

An example for fingering: Open "menu/create/text/other staff text/fingering". Unless you are very familiar with the text style and font to use, don't just type your fingering in the edit field, but select a fingering provided in the word menu. You open this word menu by right clicking with the mouse or by just pressing the application key.

chapter.title: MusicXML on the Internet
chapter.para: Since MusicXML is increasingly being used as an interchange format between different music notation software, it is increasingly being used as the canonical format to distribute musical notation over the Internet.
Therefore, there is a chance that the music you are looking for is already available on the Internet in MusicXML format.

partintro.para: Now that we have acquainted ourselves with &bmn; and know how to obtain MusicXML documents we can go on and examine in detail how &App; can be used to automatically transcribe scanned sheet music to &bmn;.

chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: The user interface of &App; closely resembles a typical editor application. At the top is a menu bar for convenient access to the most used actions. The main part of the application is a text edit window which contains the result of transcribing the currently opened MusicXML file to &bmn;.

You can use the caret to navigate inside the resulting braille music document as in other editing applications. The caret position is context sensitive. For instance, if you move the caret the status area will automatically be updated with textual information about the braille symbol currently underneath the caret.

&App; also offers the possibility to play back the score currently opened. During playback, the caret position will update synchronous to the music. Additionally, there is the possibility to play individual parts of a score, or just a single note.

question.para: Why can't I read the default output of &App; on LinuxLinux with BRLTTYBRLTTY?

answer.para: &App; uses Unicode by default to output braille and text such that sighted and blind users can read the output without major confusion.
However, the Unicode braille row is only supported by the braille display driver BRLTTY on Linux since release 3.10. You will also need the braille fonts provided on .
